title: 4 fermented, gut-healing recipes that you need right now : How to, News - India Today
text:
4 fermented, gut-healing recipes that you need right now Stomach infections come with every season change, and these recipes will help you fight them better. A + A - These gut-healing dishes will help you get over stomach infections. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/EAT SMARTER/detoxdiy.com 
Every time the season changes (and these changes are quite harsh in India), we get more prone to infections and viral fevers. For any foodie out there, stomach infections are the worst. 
This isn't just because of the fact that we won't be able to taste absolutely delicious anything before the bug says goodbye for good. Food recommended during this period is usually devoid of any masalas or spices, chillies are a big no-no, and dare you even crave a bite of anything made of flour. 
So what are your options during this bout of sickness? Get better as fast as you can, and make sure you get a good dose of these four fermented dishes. Just like the Indian staple dahi or yogurt (which you should have regularly), these easy recipes work as probiotics. Because of the fermentation they go through, these dishes are packed full of healthy bacteria that your gut needs. 
And you know what? They taste absolutely delicious. 
Also read: 3 haldi (turmeric) recipes that are as warming as tasty 
Kimchi 
This Korean wonder is all about taste and health benefits. Kimchi is a traditional fermented dish that has been around for ages, but now its benefits are taking over the world. To make it, you'll need: 2 cups cabbage, shredded; 1/2 cup carrots, grated; 1/2 cup onions, grated; 1/2 cup salt; 1 tbsp garlic, grated; 1 tbsp ginger, grated; 2 tbsp red chillies, chopped; 5 tbsp water. Kimchi is a traditional Korean fermented dish. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Eat This! 
Place all the ingredients in a very large bowl. Rub the veggies with the salt properly, and allow the whole mix to rest till it sweats and softens (around 15 minutes). Add the water, and mix the kimchi together. Shift the kimchi into mason jars, pressing them down so that no bubbles remain. Seal the jars loosely, and keep them in a warm place for a week. After that, seal them properly, and shift them to the refrigerator for storage. 
Sauerkraut 
This German pickle has been around for a while, and we've all tasted it in sandwiches or burgers. It's basically made of cabbage, and is very easy to rustle up. You'll need: 2 cups cabbage, shredded; 3 tbsp salt; 2 tsp peppercorns, crushed; 2 tsp caraway seeds, for flavour. Sauerkraut can be added to sandwiches and burgers. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/The Kitchn 
Take the cabbage and the salt in a very large bowl, and rub them together for five minutes. Allow the cabbage to sweat out by resting it for 10 minutes. Add the pepper and caraway seeds, and mix well. Press the cabbage down with some weight, like a heavy bowl or stone pestle. Cover the whole thing with cling film, and let it rest for a week. Shift the sauerkraut into mason jars, along with its water, and let it rest for another week. You can preserve it in a refrigerator. 
Also read: 2 easy recipes that'll make superfood sesame a regular part of your life 
Kanji 
This fermented drink is a Punjabi favourite. Traditionally made with carrots and beetroots during winters, it's usually a very dark shade of red or purple. You'll need: 1 cup carrots, sliced; 1 cup beetroot, sliced; Salt, to taste; 2 tsp chilli powder; 2 tsp mustard powder; 4 cups of water. Kanji is a fermented drink made in Punjab. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/vegrecipesofindia.com 
Mix all the ingredients together in a large jar. Cover the jar with a muslin cloth, and keep it out in the sun or in a warm place for five days. Make sure you stir the contents of the jar at least once every day. After five days, it should turn sour (which means it's fermented). Serve immediately, or refrigerate. 
Thandai 
Another North Indian favourite, thandai is typically made and served during spring and summer. If you like to have a glass during Holi celebrations, you can have some today. You'll need: 4 cups full-fat milk; 1/4 cup sugar; 1/4 cup almond powder; 2 tbsp poppy seeds, powdered; 2 tbsp fennel seeds, powdered; 1/2 tsp cardamom powder; 1 tsp black pepper; 1/2 tsp saffron strands. Thandai can help you celebrate good gut health. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Saveur 
Mix all the ingredients, except the pepper and saffron, in a large bowl with a whisk. Cover the bowl, and refrigerate it for a few hours. Pour the whole thandai mix through a sieve or strainer to get rid of all the lumps. Add the pepper and saffron to the sieved thandai, and stir it. Serve immediately, or refrigerate to preserve. 
A good dose of these delicious dishes can help your gut get strong enough to fight the worst stomach infections out there.
